awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physiological mechanisms involved in the allocation of energy to reproduction in corals under thermal stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Coral reefs are diverse tropical ecosystems that provide storm protection and support economic livelihoods for fishing and tourism in coastal communities.  The long-term health of reefs worldwide is being negatively impacted by increased seawater temperatures that have led to coral bleaching and widespread coral mortality, especially during the last three years.  The goal of this research is to identify characteristics and physiological strategies that lead to successful coral reproduction and long-term recovery despite bleaching.  This information can be applied to coral conservation and management efforts.  Furthermore, these findings will be incorporated into community outreach activities, as follows: in Hawaii, to develop a workshop with elementary teachers from Hawaiian immersion schools; in Washington, with Seattle MESA (Mathematics Engineering Science and Achievement for underrepresented minorities, women, at-risk and economically disadvantaged youth) to connect science fundamentals to the real world and work with teachers to develop marine biology lesson plans; and in Pennsylvania, with the School District of Philadelphia to develop hands-on classroom activities and lead field trips to the local ocean with underserved high schools populated by over 90% minority students.

Most prior coral bleaching studies have focused on the potential of adult colonies to recover and acclimatize from stress. However, future reefs will not only require the survival of adults, but will also be dependent upon the continuation of sexual reproduction despite thermal stress. Little is known about the mechanisms corals use to tolerate and successfully reproduce in stressful environments. This interdisciplinary study will characterize the physiological and phenotypic responses associated with thermal stress and quantify the impacts of coral nutrition to reproduction.  The research will focus on an important and dominant reef builder in Hawaii that has the capacity to sexually reproduce despite bleaching. The objectives are to: (1) independently track the contribution of carbon and nitrogen acquired from parental photosynthesis and heterotrophy to gamete development in bleached and unbleached colonies; (2) develop nutritional proteome profiles of bleached and unbleached parental colonies and their eggs that have relied on different trophic sources throughout gamete development; and (3) use the proteomic surveys to develop a biomarker assay for coral trophic status. The findings of this study will detect biomarkers that can serve to monitor trophic status and identify coral species that are likely to recover and reproduce after a bleaching event. Altogether these data can be applied to conservation and management efforts and the development of accurate forecasting models.

por.por_cntn:
Currently coral reefs, which are one of the most diverse ecosystems in the world, are being critically impacted by thermal stress due to global warming. The findings of this study detected biomarker molecules (proteins) that can serve to monitor coral nutrition and identified organisms that are likely to recover and reproduce after a bleaching event, improving our capacity to project the response of coral communities to thermal bleaching events. 

 

We found different metabolic responses between outer layer tissue and inner core tissue in corals that may reflect the compartmentalization of specific physiological functions and energy acquisition and allocation in each compartment. Additionally, our study reveals which metabolisms, when active, provide a significant advantage to surviving the next thermal bleaching event. In our experiments we followed bleached and non-bleached coral colonies over eight months - from bleaching through spawning and tracked the contribution of carbon and nitrogen to reproduction in bleached and unbleached coral colonies. We found fundamental differences in lipid storage and metabolic priorities that may result in variable reproductive outcomes and proteomic differences in the eggs between previously bleached and non-bleached colonies.

 

Our study also identified different energy allocation strategies depending on species and bleaching susceptibility. For example, Montipora capitata (rice coral) allocated 10% more carbon to gametes despite bleaching, with 50–80% less carbon allocated to bleached compared to non-bleached colonies. Porites compressa (finger coral) maintained carbon allocation to adult tissues, before allocating carbon to gametes. 

 

Resistant corals that survived bleaching events have high lipid content, diverse ways to acquire energy, healthy symbiont relationships with evidence of metabolite exchange, and a diverse microbiome. Susceptible corals had early signs of symbiont rejection, low lipid reserves, urea uptake for carbon and nitrogen, more abundant viral proteins, and a less diverse microbiome. 

This information can help to pinpoint which corals might survive a bleaching event and be applied to conservation and management efforts and the development of accurate forecasting models under different bleaching scenarios. 

 

Finally, we performed the first study to examine microplastics ingestion following thermal stress in corals, our results highlight the variability in the risk of microplastics ingestion among species and the importance of considering multiple drivers to project how corals will be affected by global change.

 

This study provided valuable training for a postdoctoral researcher, graduate, undergraduate and high school students that were wholly involved in research activities including field experiments, physiological, biogeochemical and molecular analytical procedures, and data analysis. Thus far, findings of this study were disseminated through 10 conference presentations, 7 peer-reviewed publications (4 published, 3 in prep), and incorporated into community outreach activities. In Hawaii, at the Hawaii Institute of Marine Biology we offered a workshop for elementary teachers from Hawaiian immersion schools and worked with teachers to develop coral biology lesson plans; and in Pennsylvania, with the School District of Philadelphia we developed hands-on classroom activities and lead field trips to the local ocean with underserved high schools populated by over 90% minority students.
